questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common type of multifetal pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
The most common type of multifetal pregnancy is dizygotic twinning, which is always dichorionic 
diamniotic. The incidence of dizygotic twins is 80% among twins. Of the monozygotic twins, monochorionic 
diamniotic is the most common (13-14%). Zygosity refers to the type of conception while chorionicity refers to the type of placentation. 313 
Sold by @itachibot Types of twin pregnancies: • Dizygotic: 2 ova are fertilized by 2 sperms to form 2 separate zygotes. • Monozygotic: Single zygote (1 ovum fertilized by 1 sperm) divides into 2. Feature 
Monozygotic 
Dizygotic Phenotype 
Identical 
Non-identical Genotype 
Identical 
Non-identical Incidence 
1:250 (constant worldwide) Varies with demograp hy Incidence after ART 
Increases 
Increases High 
Low Perinatal complication 
s

questions.question: Question 2: What is the time of division of the inner cell mass in a diamniotic monochorionic pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Diamniotic monochorionic pregnancy occurs if the division of inner cell mass takes place between 
4th - 8th day after fertilization. The timing of the division of zygote for each type of twinning is given below. Monozygotic twin types 
Time of zygote division Dichorionic diamniotic 
<72 hours 4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic ( 
more common) 8-12 days Monochorionic monoamnioti 
c 314 
Sold by @itachibot Monozygotic twin types 
Time of zygote division Conjoined twins 
>12 days

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is false regarding multifetal pregnancies?

options.a: Number of embryos implanted affects the risk of twinning
options.b: Isograft is done between monozygotic twins
options.c: Twins of opposite sex are usually dizygotic
options.d: Same sex twins having same blood group are always monozygotic

questions.explanation:
Same sex twins of the same blood group are not always monozygotic but can also be dizygotic 
twins as well. The genetic relationship between dizygotic twins is the same as any siblings. Option A: More the number of embryos transferred in IVF, more is the risk of twinning. Hence, 
single embryo transfer is being recommended by the American Society for Reproductive Medicine 
(2017) to prevent twin gestation. Option B: Isograft is done between monozygotic twins as they have HLA homology. Option C: Twins of the opposite sex are usually dizygotic. Rarely, somatic mutations or 
chromosomal aberrations can change the sex of 1 or both of the monozygotic twins.

questions.question:
Question 4: The examination findings of a pregnant woman are suggestive of her having conjoined twins. 
Which is the most common type of such twins?
questions.explanation:
Thoracopagus is the most common type of conjoined twins. Division of the inner cell mass after the 12th day of fertilization results in the development of 
conjoined or Siamese twins. Based on the parts of the body joined, they are of the following types: • Ventral • Rostral • Omphalopagus (abdomen) • Thoracopagus (upper chest) • Cephalopagus (head) • Caudal • Ischiopagus (conjoined spines at 180 angle) • Lateral • Paraphagus (side by side fusion with a shared pelvis) • Dorsal • Craniopagus (skull) • Rachipagus (vertebral arches) • Pyopagus (pelvis) Sharing of organs is common among conjoined twins. MRI imaging is done later in pregnancy for 
the evaluation of organ sharing between conjoined twins who are being planned for surgical 
separation. 315 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following can be used to calculate the incidence of multifetal gestation?
questions.explanation:
The incidence of multiple pregnancies is calculated by Hellin’s rule. According to this rule, incidence= 1 : 80(n-1), where n is the number of fetuses. Factors affecting the incidence of twin pregnancies are: • Monozygotic • ART • Dizygotic • Race • Heredity • Maternal age • Parity • Family history of twinning • Good nutritional status • Infertility therapy Option A: Tei index or myocardial performance index (MPI) is calculated using ventricular 
doppler imaging. It is used to assess cardiac function in TTTS. Option C: CHOP score is used for cardiac evaluation of recipient twin in TTTS. Option D: Kleihauer-Betke test is used to evaluate the approximate volume of fetomaternal 
hemorrhage in cases of Rh-D alloimmunization. 316 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: In which of the following instances is there an increased chance of twinning?
questions.explanation:
Increasing maternal age, family history of twinning, and conception after stopping OCPs increase 
the risk of twinning. Taller, well-built women have an increased risk of twinning compared to shorter undernourished 
women. IVF increases the risk of twinning but single embryo transfer reduces the risk of 
multifetal pregnancies. Factors affecting the incidence of twin pregnancies: • Monozygotic • ART • Dizygotic • Race • Heredity • Maternal age • Parity • Family history of twinning • Good nutritional status • Infertility therapy Note- A family history of twinning (maternal and paternal) causes an increased chance of 
twinning. It is seen that maternal history of twinning has a higher chance of twinning as 
compared to a paternal history of twinning.

questions.question: Question 7: In superfecundation, which of the following is seen?

options.a: Fertilisation of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse
options.b: Fertilisation of 2 ova released in the same cycle by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different

questions.explanation:
Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova released in the same cycle, by 
two separate acts of coitus within a short period of time. Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova in the same menstrual cycle (as 
suggested by the same gestational age) by separate acts of coitus. It can occur even after artificial 
reproductive therapy. Hence, after embryo transfer, intercourse must be avoided. Heteropaternal 
superfecundation is used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins. 
This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings. This may give rise to the doubt of 
adultery and infidelity. Superfetation is the fertilization of two ova released in different menstrual cycles. This is not seen 
in humans. The nidation and development of one fetus over another fetus is theoretically possible 
until the decidual space is obliterated by 14-16 weeks of pregnancy.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition given in the image? 305 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It is more common in monochorionic pregnancies
options.b: It cannot be detected by sonography
options.c: It is diagnosed usually after delivery
options.d: Morbidity in the co-twin is due to hypotension

questions.explanation:
317 
Sold by @itachibot The above image shows fetus compressus which appears as a tan ovoid mass compressed against 
the fetal membranes. It can be detected early by sonography. In multifetal pregnancies, if one of the fetuses dies early in pregnancy, the surviving fetus 
continues to develop normally. It can lead to the following outcomes: Factors affecting the prognosis of the surviving twin: • Gestational age at fetal death: 2nd and 3rd trimester deaths increase the risk of morbidity in the 
surviving twin • Chorionicity: Monochorionic twins with early fetal death have an increased risk of morbidity in 
the surviving twin. This is due to neurological abnormality and vascular anastomoses. • Duration between fetal demise and delivery of surviving twin • Surviving twin may be born preterm leading to an increased risk of fetal demise Death in the surviving twin occurs mostly due to vascular anastomoses between the twins. The 
surviving twin can develop sudden hypotension due to these anatomoses after fetal demise. Outcome 
Type Disappears 
Vanishing twin Gets compressed 
Fetus compres 
sus Fetus papyrace 
us Flattened through desiccatio 
n

questions.question:
Question 9: A woman is diagnosed to have twins during her dating scan. What is the most common 
presentation in such pregnancies?
questions.explanation:
The most common presentation in twins is both vertex/ cephalo-cephalic presentation (60%). The 
other presentations include: • Cephalo-Breech (20%) • Breech-Cephalic (10%) • Breech-Breech (6-10%) • Transverse-Transverse (Rarest) Mode of delivery depends on the presentation of the 1st twin as: Presentation of the 1st twin 
Mode of deliver 
y Vertex 
Vaginal Breech 
Caesarean secti 
on Transverse 
Caesarean secti 
on 318 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is:
questions.explanation:
The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is 11-14 weeks. Twin pregnancies should ideally be dated when the crown–rump length (CRL) measurement is 
between 45 and 84 mm (i.e. 11 + 0 to 13 + 6 weeks of gestation). Chorionicity should be ideally determined between 11 + 0 and 13 + 6 weeks of gestation (the 
earliest time to identify chorionicity is 7 weeks). This is done using the membrane thickness at the 
site of insertion of the amniotic membrane into the placenta. The T■sign (in monochorionic 
twins) or lambda sign (in dichorionic twins) can be seen here. As the determination of chorionicity 
is most accurate when the amnion and chorion have not yet been fused, the first■trimester scan 
in twin pregnancy is highly important. Markers of dichorionicity include 4 layers of membranes between the twins, membrane thickness 
>2mm, different sex of twins, 2 different placentas, and positive twin peak sign. Women with an uncomplicated dichorionic twin pregnancy should have a first■trimester scan, a 
detailed second■trimester scan, and scans every 4 weeks thereafter. Women with uncomplicated monochorionic twins should have a first■trimester scan and then 
scans every 2 weeks from 16 weeks onwards. This is done in order to detect TTTS and TAPS in a 
timely manner.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 35-year-old woman conceived after being treated for infertility. Her USG scan is given 
below. What is her diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This is 
also known as the lambda sign or delta sign. In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and 
2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. This 
gives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the intervening 
membrane. 319 
Sold by @itachibot Sonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following: • Number of placental masses - 2 • Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta sign • Thickness of intervening membranes  2mm The best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.

questions.question:
Question 12: A primigravida presents to the ANC clinic for the first time at 14 weeks of gestation. She 
complains of excessive nausea and vomiting. On examination, fundal height is midway 
between pubic symphysis and umbilicus. The T sign in seen on USG. What is her diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the T sign seen on USG points towards a diagnosis 
of monochorionic diamniotic twins. The T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. In monochorionic 
diamniotic twins, the separating membrane is made up only by the two amniotic membranes with 
no intervening chorion. This can be seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning of 
the second trimester. Symptoms of multifetal pregnancy: • Increased nausea and vomiting in early months • Palpitations and shortness of breath • Increased swelling of legs, varicose veins and haemorrhoids • Unusual rate of uterine growth • Excessive fetal movements Signs of multifetal pregnancy: • Increased weight gain • Hypertension 320 
Sold by @itachibot • Barrel shaped abdomen • Increased fundal height and abdominal girth • Multiple fetal parts • Palpation of 2 fetal heads • FHS at different spots with FHR difference of at least 10bpm Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy is terminated between 34-37 weeks+6 days. The below image shows the T sign.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following images depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy? 307 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The USG in image 2 depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy. It is identified by the T sign. In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the intervening membrane has only 2 layers (i.e) 2 amnions. 
This thin membrane is seen ending at the common placenta giving rise to the T sign. 321 
Sold by @itachibot Sonographic assessment of monochorionicity is done by observing the following: • Single placental mass • Presence of intervening membrane - T sign • Thin intervening membrane <2mm The best time of delivery of monochorionic diamniotic twins is 34 - 37weeks + 6 days. Image 1: Dichorionic twins with twin peak or lambda sign Image 3: Monochorionic monoamniotic twins with no intervening membranes between them Image 4: Triplets with 3 separate gestational sacs

questions.question:
Question 14: A mother with twin pregnancy underwent routine USG. Estimated fetal weights were 
calculated for both twins. What is the criteria to diagnose pathological discordant growth in 
this pregnancy?

options.a: Difference of >25% with larger twin as index
options.b: Difference of <50% with larger twin as index
options.c: Difference of >50% with smaller twin as index
options.d: Difference of >20% with larger twin as index

questions.explanation:
A difference in estimated fetal weight of >20% with larger twin as index is one of the criteria 
for diagnosing discordant growth. Discordant growth is the unequal size/ weight among the fetuses in a multifetal gestation. It can 
be diagnosed by either of the following: • Estimated fetal weight difference > 20% • Discordance = (weight of larger twin - weight of smaller twin/weight of larger twin) x 100 Discordant growth in monochorionic twins is due to placental vascular anastomoses. In 
dichorionic twins, it occurs due to differences in genetic growth potential and suboptimal 
implantation site for one of the fetuses.

questions.question:
Question 15: In a woman receiving artificial reproductive therapy, the inner cell mass divides on the 7th 
day. Which of the following complications is not seen in the resulting multifetal pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
322 
Sold by @itachibot The division of the inner cell mass on the 7th day will result in monochorionic diamniotic type of 
twin pregnancy. Cord entanglement is seen in monoamniotic twins and not in diamniotic twins. The timing of the division of zygote for each type of twinning is given below. Complications in monochorionic diamniotic twins occur due to placental vascular anastomoses. 
They include: • Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) • Twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP) or acardiac twin • Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome (TAPS) Monochorionic monoamniotic twins have a high fetal death rate. This is due to the following 
complications: • Preterm birth • Congenital anomalies • Low birth weight • Cord entanglement Monozygotic types 
Time of zygote division Dichorionic diamniotic 
<72 hours 4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic ( 
more common) 8-12 days Monochorionic monoamnioti 
c Conjoined twins 
>12 days

questions.question:
Question 16: What is the most common type of placental vascular anastomoses seen in monochorionic 
twin pregnancies?
questions.explanation:
Artery-vein anastomoses are most commonly seen in monochorionic pregnancies. All monochorionic placentas have anastomoses that can be: • Superficial artery-vein • Deep artery-vein • Artery-artery • Vein-vein • One vessel with connections to multiple arteries and veins These anastomoses are not functional as long as the fetuses are hemodynamically balanced. When 
a pressure gradient develops between the fetuses, complications can occur like: • TTTS - Twin-twin transfusion syndrome • TAPS - Twin anemia polycythemia sequence 323 
Sold by @itachibot • TRAP - Twin reversed arterial perfusion The most common complication in monochorionic twins is twin-twin transfusion syndrome 
(TTTS). Deep artery-vein anastomosis is the pathology seen in this condition.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 26-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, is diagnosed to have twin-twin transfusion 
syndrome. Which of the following statements is true regarding the recipient twin in this 
condition?

options.b: It is called the stuck twin

questions.explanation:
Congestive heart failure is seen in the recipient twin. Twin-twin transfusion syndrome is a deep arteriovenous anastomotic complication seen 
in monochorionic diamniotic twins. Deoxygenated blood from the donor enters through the 
anastomosis into a shared cotyledon for oxygen exchange. Oxygenated blood is taken up by the 
recipient twin causing imbalance in the blood volumes. Diagnosis of TTTS depends on 2 USG criteria: • Monochorionic diamniotic gestation • Hydramnios (DVP>8cm) in one twin and oligohydramnios (DVP<2cm) in the other twin Treatment modalities for TTTS: • Serial amnioreduction • Laser ablation of vascular placental anastomoses • Selective fetal termination Note: Donor twin is called the stuck twin as the oligohydramnios limits fetal movement. Donor twin characteristics 
Recipient twin characteristics Oliguria 
Polyuria Oligohydramnios 
Polyhydramnios Hypotension 
Hypertension Anaemia 
Polycythemia Activation of atrial natriureti 
c peptide (ANP) Activation of renin-angiotens 
in-aldosterone system (RAAS) Congestive cardiac failure, pr 
emature rupture of membran 
es Renal failure, growth restricti 
on, pulmonary hypoplasia, co 
ntractures

questions.question:
Question 18: The ultrasound findings in a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy are indicative of 
poly-oli syndrome. What is the pathology seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
In poly - oli or polyhydramnios - oligohydramnios syndrome, the basic pathology is the presence 
of a deep artery-vein anastomosis. TTTS can present as poly-oli syndrome or twin oligohydramnios polyhydramnios syndrome 
(TOPS). This is usually seen in mid-pregnancy. In this syndrome, there is decreased donor renal 
perfusion, causing oliguria and oligohydramnios. Because of the anastomosis, the recipient twin 324 
Sold by @itachibot has increased renal perfusion and increased urine production causing polyhydramnios. Donor twin characteristics 
Recipient twin characteristics Oliguria 
Polyuria Oligohydramnios 
Polyhydramnios Hypotension 
Hypertension Anemia 
Polycythemia Renal failure 
Congestive cardiac failure Growth restriction 
Premature rupture of membr 
anes Pulmonary hypoplasia 
Hyperbilirubinemia Contractures

questions.question: Question 19: Ultrasound findings in a twin pregnancy are given below:
questions.explanation:
The given USG findings are indicative of twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) with twin A 
being the recipient and twin B being the donor twin. Oligohydramnios (AFI<5cm), absent urine 
and abnormal Doppler flow findings in the donor twin indicate stage III of twin-twin transfusion 
syndrome according to Quintero staging. Quintero staging system for TTTS classification: Stag 
e USG findings I

questions.question:
Question 20: An anxious mother pregnant with twins was recently diagnosed with twin-twin transfusion 
syndrome. She wants to know the possible fetal outcome of the pregnancy. Which of the 
following investigations can be used to predict this?
questions.explanation:
In twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), the fetal outcome depends on the cardiac function of 
the recipient twin. Tei index or myocardial performance index (MPI) is used to assess the 325 
Sold by @itachibot ventricular function using doppler. Option A: Deepest vertical pocket on USG is used to diagnose polyhydramnios-oligohydramnios in 
TTTS. Options B and D: Fetal haemoglobin and MCA peak systolic velocity are used to diagnose TAPS 
(Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome).

questions.question:
Question 21: What is/are the placental vascular abnormality that can be seen in the condition depicted in 
the image given below?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows an acardius acephalus fetus. This refers to the acardiac twin seen in twin 
reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP). Both artery-artery and vein-vein anastomosis can be seen in 
TRAP. TRAP is a placental vascular anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic twins. In this 
disorder, deoxygenated blood from the donor twin enters the recipient twin through the 
anastomosis and supplies the lower half of the recipient’s body. Hence, the heart and upper body 
of the recipient is poorly developed. The below image depicts the circulation pattern seen in TRAP. Based on the supply of deoxygenated blood, the recipient twin might have the following fates: The donor twin develops high output cardiac failure. The treatment for this condition is radiofrequency ablation of the acardiac or recipient twin. Fate 
Type Acardius acephalus Lower body is perfused with f 
ailed head growth Acardius myelecephal 
us Partially developed head with identifiable limbs 326 
Sold by @itachibot Fate 
Type No recognizable structure 
Acardius amorphous

questions.question:
Question 22: A 25-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, goes into labour. Following the vaginal delivery of 
the first twin, she was taken to the OT for internal version. What could have been the possible 
indication for this procedure?
questions.explanation:
The second twin being in transverse lie is the only indication for internal version in modern 
obstetrics. In a twin pregnancy, if the first twin has vertex presentation, vaginal delivery can be performed. 
Following the vaginal delivery of the first twin, if the second twin is in transverse lie, it is 
corrected by external version (preferably cephalic) into a longitudinal lie. If external version fails 
and the membranes are intact, internal version is done under general anaesthesia, followed by 
breech extraction. If the membranes are ruptured, caesarean section is done immediately. Mode of delivery depends on the presentation of the 1st twin: Presentation of the 1st twin 
Mode of deliver 
y Vertex 
Vaginal Breech 
Caesarean secti 
on Transverse 
Caesarean secti

questions.question: Question 23: Identify this condition.
questions.explanation:
The given specimen depicts a monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy as: • 2 umbilical cords are arising from 1 placenta (monochorionic) • No intervening amniotic membrane is attached to the placenta. This means that both fetuses 
must have been inside a single amniotic cavity (monoamniotic). Option B: In Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy, on gross examination, there will be 1 placenta 
and intervening 2 layers of amnion attached to the placenta. In this type of pregnancy, each fetus 
will have its own amniotic cavity (diamniotic) with a shared placenta (monochorionic). This is 
seen if the fertilized zygote divides into 2 between 4-8 days. The below given gross image of monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy shows two umbilical cords 
arising separately from the placenta with the intervening amniotic membrane held by the forceps. 327 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: In dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy each fetus has it’s own amnion & chorion. 
The placentas here may be fused or separate. This is seen in dizygotic twins as well as 
monozygotic twins that divide within 0-4 days. Option A: Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) most commonly complicates 
monochorionic (single placenta) twin pregnancy. In TTTS blood is transfused from the donor twin 
to the recipient twin through the abnormal vascular connections within the placenta leaving the 
donor anemic while the recipient becomes polycythemic. The box below describes the type of amnion and chorion seen in different types of twins 
depending on the time of division. Dizygotic twins 
Dichorionic diamniotic Dichorionic diamnioticMono

questions.question:
Question 24: 311 
Sold by @itachibot A pregnant woman was diagnosed with triplets on ultrasound. The obstetrician has planned 
to do a selective fetal reduction of one of the fetuses to improve the outcome of the 
pregnancy. What is the ideal timing and the method for the procedure?
questions.explanation:
Selective fetal reduction is done between 10-13 weeks via intracardiac injection of KCl. In multi-chorionic multifetal gestations, selective reduction of the smallest or anomalous 
fetus/fetuses is done to increase the chance of survival of the other fetuses. Laser ablation or bipolar coagulation of the umbilical cord of the targeted fetus is done. This 
protects the surviving fetuses from the adverse effects of the drug.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an 
antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was 
pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech 
position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two 
occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next?

options.a: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
options.c: Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.explanation:
Immediate cesarean section is done as the first twin is in breech presentation. Uncomplicated 
dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies are terminated at 38 weeks of gestation. Timing of delivery depends on the type of twin pregnancy: The mode of delivery depends on the 1st twin: After delivery of 1st twin, if the 2nd twin is in breech, assisted breech delivery is done. If the 2nd 
twin is in a transverse lie, the internal podalic version is done under GA in the OT followed by 
breech extraction. Complications in attempting vaginal delivery in non-vertex presentation (i.e) transverse and 
breech: • Interlocking of twins • Fetal head trapping above the cervix • Umbilical cord prolapse 329 
Sold by @itachibot According to ACOG criteria (2019), preeclampsia requires proteinuria of grade 2+ or more. In the 
case of pre-eclampsia, termination of pregnancy must be done at 37 weeks. According to the 
updated criteria, this patient does not have pre-eclampsia. Hence, a Caesarean section can be 
done at 38 weeks as for any uncomplicated DCDA twin pregnancy. Type of twin pregnancy 
Timing of delivery Dichorionic diamniotic 
38 weeks Monochorionic diamniotic 
34 - 37 weeks + 6 days 32 - 34 weeks by Caesarean s 
ection Monochorionic monoamn 
iotic 1st twin presentatio 
n Mode of delive 
ry Vertex 
Vaginal Breech 
Cesarean secti 
on Transverse 
Cesarean secti 
on

questions.question:
Question 26: A 26-year-old primigravida with dichorionic diamniotic twins presents to the clinic in active 
labor. The first twin is delivered vaginally but the second has a transverse lie. A trial of ECV 
was unsuccessful. What is not a complication of the procedure performed next for the 
delivery of the second twin?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical procedure is suggestive of internal podalic version for the second twin. Shoulder 
presentation, and not face presentation, is a complication of this procedure. The complications seen with internal podalic version are as follows: • Maternal- • Failure of the procedure • Uterine rupture • Vaginal and perineal trauma • Placental abruption • Postpartum haemorrhage • Ascending infection • Anaesthetic risks • Fetal- • Cord prolapse • Shoulder presentation with prolapsed arm • Skeletal injury (femur, hips, humerus, skull) • Visceral injury (kidney, liver, spleen) 330 
Sold by @itachibot • Neural injury (facial nerve) • Hypoxic brain injury • Death 331 
Sold by @itachibot Ectopic Pregnancy
